Then be tired no more, here is how to get rid of it. 1) Go to windows start --> RUN OR windows key + R 2) Type regedit and hit OK (OR hit ENTER key) 3) Go to HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT 3) Go to lnkfile 4) Delete the IsShortcut registry value 5) Exit regedit 6) Restart windows Voila, shortcut arrows be gone!

Many businesses loose out on valuable sales by simply ignoring the simple things. After my home-made crossover cable stopped working, I decided that I wanted a USB data transfer cable (of course I could always try to repair the cable, but I am tired of the exposed pieces of wire that stick out like a sore tooth). My first stop was a small boutique in a well established mall. Me : Do you have any USB cables to connect two computers? He : Nah, we doh have any USB data transfer cables. Me : but I see a whole bunch a USB cables on the other side? (wishful thinking of course) He : Nah, those are USB extensions. We should get some by next week. Me : OK (walks away) No business, especially businesses that have a least one workstation (this one did) should be without a simple stock inventory system. Use Access, Excel, anything, but you should never be without stock. You should always recognize when an item has reached it’s reorder level and quickly refill. My second stop several days later was a computer sales/internet café. Me : You have any USB data transfer cables. He 1 : Yeah we should have some somewhere around here (he looks and consults another attendant) He 2 : What you want the cable for? Me : To connect two computers. He 2 : Nah, we doh have that. Me : OK (walks away) They could have at least informed me when they would be getting some, or given me the assurance that they would contact their supplier and give me some sort of discount. Better yet they could have taken my email or telephone number and contacted me when they got some cables. In hind sight I could have requested this but this my rant not theirs.

Most parts of Trinidad (I specify Trinidad for the benefit of my international audience) have a taxi stand that services that particular part of the country. El Socorro is no exception. Taxis are almost always shared between 4 to 5 passengers. It costs $2.00 if your destination is anywhere on the main road (less than a mile long). If your destination is on a street attached to the main road, the fare is $2.50 and if it is on a street that is attached to a street that is attached to the main road and beyond (not including the main road itself of course) the fare is $3.00. The exception to this rule is any destination across the highway (the end of the main road meets the highway), in which case the fare is $3.00. To go from anywhere in El Socorro back to the taxi stand is always $2.00 regardless of where the taxi collects you. Keep in mind that you cannot call a taxi, you simply wait for one to pass by. The rationale behind this complex pricing scheme is that off route destinations (streets other than the main road) takes the taxi driver more time to complete his trip and thus reduces his daily profits. I argue that this is not always true since a street off the main road closer to the beginning of the main road takes as much time as a destination along the end of the main road. Be this as it may be, my real gripe is that passengers who live along the end of the main road are inconvenienced (and loose time and money) by passengers who go off route before them. Thus, the double standard here is that while these easily inconvenienced taxi drivers take compensation i.e. (the extra 50 cents and a dollar) for passengers going off-route, they did not find it necessary to extend the same principle to passengers who are inconvenienced by those other passengers who inconvenienced the driver in the first place. Therefore, I should have a reduced fare if I travel with a passenger that inconveniences me.

Yet another conversation with yet another person (and no, I am not talking to myself) had me thinking way into the night and keying my thoughts onto magnetised plates. As much as we dislike failure and under achievement, and so much that is negative, it is necessary in order for us to appreciate and celebrate success, and all other things that are positive. In order for me to be above average someone else must be below average. Thinking about this too much I cannot help but think about sweat shop workers in China (just one of many examples and in no way trying to be stereotypical, if that is possible) repetitively hammering away at pairs of sneakers, or t-shirts, or plastic bowls, or colorful plastic toys to be overpriced and sold to the overachievers -- Pause, think about how to continue this post, change title (previous title was 'Life is a balance') -- I feel that even though slavery was abolished some years ago, it still exists today, and must always exist in one form or the other. It is now easier to fool ourselves into thinking that we are free. I argue that what we now have are better odds of being a slave master, which I guess makes it better, which means we are progressing, but to what? Is it possible that some day both extremes will converge, there will be no master and slave and we will exist as human beings equally sharing everything and equally working for the collective betterment of us all (and not primarily ourselves). The bottom line is this, for things to exist we must have relativeness (to coin a new term) or extremes. There can be no light without darkness, no good without bad. It is fundamental to life as we know it. Even if it was possible to exist without relativeness we would not be able to describe it or understand it in a system that depends on relativeness which I guess makes this whole argument baseless and stupid but thought provoking nonetheless. Is this what you call a circular argument? If yes, then the revised title of this post is quite appropriate.

My first report in Crystal involved calculating the Sum of Averages at different group levels. Crystal does not allow you to combine Summary functions e.g. Sum ( Avg ( amount )) is not allowed. What you can do is create your total manually using a global variable and a reset and display formula. This works well if you total is in the footer. I needed my totals to be in the header so I had to use subreports to calculate the totals. This is fast, but not fast enough so I am going to use a stored procedure to perform most of the calculations on the Server side, my only limitation before was that I didn't know how to simulate the IIF on SQL Server. Now I know (see previous tip).
Select IIF(field>=0,"positive", "negative") as number from table Using SQL Server you have to use the CASE command SELECT number = CASE WHEN field >= 0 THEN "positive" ELSE "negative" END from table
